docs.lead_paragraph: Gary L. Bauer was in his hotel lobby taking questions from a handful of reporters when Steve Forbes blew by, trailed by stampeding cameramen and the two guys in pink pig suits who accompany him everywhere, waving signs that say, ''Cut pork!'' and ''Tax meat!'' Nearly knocking over his fellow candidate's wife, Carol Bauer, Mr. Forbes paused: ''Oh! Sorry,'' he said, patting her back. ''Nice to see you, Steve,'' she called after him, as he and the crowd charged on.

headline.main: Down in Polls, Bauer Clings To the Upside: Pushing Issues
headline.kicker: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: IN THE PACK -- CAMPAIGN SKETCHBOOK

docs.abstract: Interview with Republican presidential candidate Gary L Bauer, who trails badly in polls (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding ''Once More, the Question of Abortion Dogs McCain'' (news article, Jan. 27), why don't those asking a hypothetical question concerning one's teenage daughter and an unplanned pregnancy ever ask what the politician would do if his teenage son ever fathered a child? This is not to shift the focus away from a woman's right to choose but instead to recognize that teenage boys and grown men need to take an equally active role in birth control. LAURENT FISHER New York, Jan. 27, 2000
docs.abstract: Letter from Laurent Fisher says people who ask Sen John McCain hypothetical question about teenage daughter's unplanned pregnancy should also question what he would do if teenage son fathered child (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: FORGET the recent wild storms in Europe; scientists say that another kind of weather is about to turn bad, the weather in space, which can produce a variety of effects on earth, including radiation doses for people on jets. The doses are not an issue for occasional travelers or even those who fly fairly regularly, but are of some concern for flight crews, passengers who fly dozens of times a year and for pregnant women, radiation experts say.

headline.main: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; Latest Concern for Fliers: Bad Weather on the Sun

docs.abstract: Correspondent's Report on scientists' warnings that solar activity will peak in coming year, with increase in sunspots and solar flares that result in vastly increased numbers of subatomic particles; activity causes radio broadcast disruptions on earth, but also may increase radiation for people in airplanes; European airlines will begin treating flight crews as radiation workers, explaining risks of low-level doses and in some cases grounding pregnant crew members (M)
docs.snippet: FORGET the recent wild storms in Europe; scientists say that another kind of weather is about to turn bad, the weather in space, which can produce a variety of effects on earth, including radiation doses for people on jets.    The doses are not an...

docs.lead_paragraph: A Queens abortion clinic that hired a doctor who had been suspended by a hospital for carving his initials into a patient's stomach was told by a psychiatrist that the doctor apparently suffered from a brain disorder, the clinic president acknowledged yesterday. A few days after the doctor, Allan Zarkin, 61, began work at the clinic, clinic officials received a letter from a psychiatrist hired by Dr. Zarkin's lawyer saying that the doctor apparently suffered from a frontal lobe disorder. The psychiatrist, Dr. Mark Mills, said that Dr. Zarkin was still able to ''evaluate and treat patients'' but that his work should be carefully monitored.

headline.main: Clinic Says It Was Told Doctor Had Brain Ailment

docs.abstract: Merle Hoffman, president of Queens abortion clinic, says she did not know when she hired Dr Allan Zarkin that he had been fired from Beth Israel Medical Center for carving his initials into patient's stomach; says she later received letter from psychiatrist hired by Zarkin's lawyer saying doctor apparently suffered from frontal lobe disorder, and that his work should be carefully monitored; Zarkin's predecessor at clinic, Dr Enayat Hakim Elahi, claims he heard rumors about Beth Israel incident but found it so incredible that he did not report it to Hoffman; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A Queens abortion clinic that hired a doctor who had been suspended by a hospital for carving his initials into a patient's stomach was told by a psychiatrist that the doctor apparently suffered from a brain disorder, the clinic president...

docs.lead_paragraph: As called for in the Constitution, South Africa's Parliament passed a far-reaching bill this week explicitly outlawing discrimination on the basis of race, ethnicity and sex. The bill would also ban discrimination against homosexuals, pregnant women and the disabled and bar the malicious use of derogatory labels for blacks and other people of color. And it would create a special group of judges, specially approved by the government, to hear cases against accused law breakers.

headline.main: South Africa Codifies Ban on Bias In Constitution

docs.abstract: South Africa's Parliament passes far-reaching bill explicity outlawing discrimination on basis of race, ethnicity and sex; bill would also ban discrimination against homosexuals, pregnant women and the disabled and bar malicious use of derogatory labels for blacks and other people of color; protection extended in earlier draft to poor people, foreigners and people infected with HIV is removed after protests from business leaders and others (M)
